metadata.case_name: Appellant (Partner of Happy Book Stall) v. State

facts.text: Appellant is one of four partners of a firm which owns a book-stall named Happy Book Stall in Bombay.

Accused Nos. 1, 2, 3, 4 (partners including appellant as accused No. 2) found in possession for purpose of sale of obscene book 'Lady Chatterley's Lover' unexpurgated edition on 12th December 1959 at Bombay.
Appellant (Gokuldas Shamji? Wait, text says appellant accused No.2 on first count, Gokuldas Shamji sold to bogus customer Ali Raza Sayeed Hasan a copy of the book on 12th December 1959.
Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, III Court, Esplanade, Bombay convicted all partners on first count (possession), fined each Rs. 20 or one week's simple imprisonment in default.
Gokuldas Shamji additionally convicted on second count (sale), further fine Rs. 20 or like imprisonment.
Magistrate held the book obscene for purposes of S.292 IPC.
Appellant filed revision in Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 1149 of 1961, decision against him dated February 6, 1962.
Prosecution examined two witnesses: test purchaser Ali Raza Sayeed Hasan and Inspector of Vigilance Department, proving possession and sale (facts not denied). Inspector gave reasons for obscenity.
Defence witness Mr. Mulkraj Anand (writer and art critic) testified that the novel has considerable literary merit, is a classic, and not obscene despite indelicate theme.

legal_issues.text: Validity of S.292 IPC as restriction on freedom of speech and expression under Art.19(1)(a), whether saved by Art.19(2).
Proper interpretation of 'obscene' under S.292 IPC and its application to 'Lady Chatterley's Lover'.
Whether possession or sale under S.292 requires knowledge that the object is obscene (mens rea as to obscenity).

petitioner_arguments.text: S.292 IPC void as impermissible and vague restriction on Art.19(1)(a), not saved by cl.(2).
Book not obscene if S.292 properly construed: consider book as whole, literary merit outweighs obscenity; no stray passages suffice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.292 IPC; rejects Queen v. Hicklin test, prefers modern tests from England/US (overall effect, redeeming social value)

petitioner_arguments.text: Punishable possession/sale requires intention to corrupt public/purchasers.
Work of art/literary merit not obscene even if treats sex/nudity; standard of normal person (mens sana in corpore sano), not immature/abnormal.

respondent_arguments.text: Book is obscene; applied Hicklin test.

court_reasoning.text: S.292 valid: embodies reasonable restriction on Art.19(1)(a) in interests of public decency/morality; introduced by Obscene Publications Act 1925 per international convention; obscenity not protected by free speech.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Obscenity offensive to modesty/decency; poor value in propagating ideas; medical books exception due to social utility.

court_reasoning.text: No knowledge of obscenity required: S.292 does not specify 'knowingly'; strict liability to avoid defences; mens rea for sale/possession inferred from circumstances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prosecution need not prove knowledge of obscenity; appellant as bookseller infers intent.

court_reasoning.text: Test for obscenity: Modified Hicklin - consider obscene matter separately and in context of whole; art must preponderate over obscenity or obscenity trivial; judged by community standards, potential to deprave/corrupt open minds, appealing to prurient interest without preponderating social purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Treating with sex/nudity not per se obscene; balance freedom vs. decency/morality.

court_reasoning.text: Book 'Lady Chatterley's Lover' obscene: detailed sexual descriptions, profane language, no preponderating social value for Indian community; written to shock, phallic novel.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Portions pass permissible limits; literary merit insufficient to outweigh obscenity.

holdings.text: No mens rea required for knowledge of obscenity under S.292.
Obscene if treats sex appealing to carnal side without preponderating social purpose, judged by community mores; book obscene.

precedents_cited.relevance: Test of obscenity: tendency to deprave and corrupt open minds; adopted with modification.
Obscenity lacks constitutional protection; consider whole work; varying tests discussed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Manual Enterprises Inc. v. Edward Day
Regina v. Martin Secker and Warburg Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Charge to jury on hard-core pornography.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Sale/possession of obscene books; valid restriction; defines offence; no knowledge of obscenity required.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Freedom of speech subject to restrictions for decency/morality; S.292 saved.

statutes_cited.name: Obscene Publications Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Act 7 of 1925 introducing S.292 to implement international convention.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court right in upholding conviction under S.292 IPC for possession and sale of obscene book 'Lady Chatterley's Lover'.

key_quotes.text: I think the test of obscenity is this, whether the tendency of the matter charged as obscenity is to deprave and corrupt those whose minds are open to such immoral influences...
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Section 292, Indian Penal Code deals with obscenity in this sense and cannot thus be said to be invalid in view of the second clause of Art. 19.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: obscenity without a preponderating social purpose or profit cannot have the constitutional protection of free speech and expression
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on test for obscenity.
